segments.text: Well, we were tidying up the pre-war bit.
You were asking questions.
I think we ought to get a move on and talk about the wartime period.
All right.
Or have you got anything else there?
No.
As a matter of fact, you've answered my questions there.
Now, when did you develop an interest in the submarines?
This is the first time I contact you with the war.
Well, we developed an interest in submarines before the war.
Because we were measuring gravity in submarines.
We didn't get much done before the war because something was always going wrong.
There were these crises, the Munich crisis, for example, stopped us using a submarine.
I didn't ever go out in the submarines before the war.
This other man, Brown, was doing that.
I never had pretty much to do with submarines during the war.
Well, shall I?
start talking about how I got involved with the Navy.
Right, exactly.
That's where I want you to begin, and then talk about minesweeping.
Yes.
Well, it seemed to me, about 1938, that it was likely there was going to be a war.
Actually, I didn't think there was, but I mean, there was obviously a reasonable possibility of it.
And I thought it would be nice to keep our small group together.

We had, we were a very small group, there was this man I've talked about, Brown, who'd been doing the work on the submarines, there was myself, there was this assistant, and a couple of graduate students, so there were five or six of us.
And I thought it might be nice to keep the work, the group together and
to the war and also relevant to our peacetime interests.
And Ewing had much the same idea about the same time.
And I had quite a struggle actually to get into the Navy, to get the Admiralty to accept the idea at all.
The Admiralty Scientific Organization before the war was somewhat unsuccessful.
They had a rather low prestige at the service.
They were paid a bit less than the corresponding naval officers.
They had a chip on their shoulder about this.
And there'd been very little money, of course, for the services between the wars.
I mean, you just had one war and you'd won it.
Naturally, you don't spend a lot of money on defense.
And then this attitude hung over into the Hitler period.
The defense budgets were opposed every year.
in detail by the Labour Party and there was always a row every year about the financing of defence.
And they'd been in a very poor way so far as developing the things that needed to be developed.
Well, I went round and I saw the man who was looking after recruiting scientific personnel and I said, look, why don't you take the whole thing as a package deal?
And he said that he estimated the number of scientists required by the Navy at 30.
number of extra ones if war broke out.
And I said I didn't much believe it.
We went on and I think the thing that finally decided me was that I'd discovered how sonar worked and what the frequencies were and everything.
Because we'd been out with the naval ship doing seismic work and I'd kept my eyes open and learnt quite a lot about what the navy was doing and so on.
And I think he thought it was safer to have me inside than wandering around outside.
At any rate, I started off by going to the anti-submarine establishment.
And this was a pretty unsatisfactory organization.
And I think I was building up for a row with the management of it when I was suddenly removed.
I think they saw the red light that I was going to be a bloody nuisance.
And so I suddenly got transferred to protecting ships from magnetic mines.
Now, I've told this story, I think I've told it in print.
I wrote a... Now, I'm not sure that I have, but let me tell you the story.
You're not going to publish this stuff, are you?
It's an understanding between us that you aren't going to publish this stuff with descriptions to me.
I mean, I don't want suits for the library.
Cut it off from me.
Okay.
Next piece, I have placed certain restrictions on it.
Well, I found myself working with a group who were interested in demagnetizing ships to prevent them being blown up by magnetic mines.
And it was a real comic opera show.
I was put to work with a man whose name I will not mention.
And he was a little older than me, probably five or ten years older than me.
And he put me to stand on the quay.
And he made a measurement, and when he made his measurement, he waved his arm, and I then said, move her along 10 feet, Skipper.
And Skipper moved the boat along a key 10 feet, and he took another measurement.
Well, the only question was how long I'd let this go on for.
I was 30, 31 at the time, and I let it go on for a day or two, and then fate played into my hands.
Along came
a committee which was inquiring into the Admiralty's use of scientific manpower.
And the chairman of it was Ray Fowler, a well-known physicist, a friend of mine, son-in-law of Rutherford's, married Rutherford's daughter.
And he came up to me and said, what are you doing?
And I described it in just the words I've given you now.
And he said, do you think this is a good thing?
And I said, well, you can judge that.
And then I thought, this might not be sufficient, so I thought I'd better emphasize the matter.
So I went around that evening and saw the admiral, who was staying in a hotel in Portsmouth, who was in charge of all the anti-mine operations.
And I went to see him and I said, look, we're having trouble about reports.
Old so-and-so is running this show, can't make up his mind whether the ship sailed from left to right or right to left.
And we redrafted the diagram several times and there's been a lot of delay in getting the reports out.
But I have black market copies of these reports of which I can supply you.
And he looked at me and said, I think I'd like one.
So I wasn't sure what he was going to do.
I thought he might be very indignant because he's now the lead admiral.
And so I said, well, that's all right.
I'll regularly supply reports a week or two ahead on their issue.
And then the next day, I was, in the middle of the morning, I was asked to go around and

meet a committee and I found my admiral in the chair and my friend from the committee that was inquiring into admiralty who's a scientific manpower next to him and a number of other civilians and naval officers there.
And they said, I wasn't sure what was going to happen, but they said, look, will you take over the direction of this show?
And I said, what show precisely?
And they, rather to my surprise, said, not only the things I've been concerned with, but a rather wider group of things.
And I said, yes, I'd be pleased to take it over, but I have a condition.
And they said, well, what's the condition?
I said that six people named by me be removed from the project.
And I then got rid of all, they said they agreed to this, and I got rid of all the permits that the servants had.
we reached an agreement that they would form a small group not responsible to me to investigate the longer term matters.
Well, the war was only going to last a finite time, so I wasn't very interested in anything that the civil service called a longer term project.
So then the first time I was in charge of something, the first time in my life when I'd ever had a group of people responsible to me.
I had a naval officer member, a lieutenant commander called Hex Lewis, and he and I were responsible for this group.
And there were, at the peak of the thing, we had 50 naval officers and about 50 civilians and a decent sized group.
It was the first time I'd ever been able really to do things on a large scale and had a
what was really a project.
This was the start.
I'd learnt how to manipulate the Navy, how to get your way, you see, by a sort of rather cheerful openness and assuming that everything would come out right and so on.
I must have learnt awfully quickly because I had never before been charged of anything more than two graduate students.
Before the war I'd had two graduate students and suddenly I'd got this project and the naval officer, who was my opposite number, was very helpful to me.
He knew much more than I did about how the world worked and how to run things.
And we had the greatest fun with it.
We had this tremendous success with the acoustic mine, with the demagnetizing of ships and so on.
We had to move out of Portsmouth because it was being bombed and we were spending all our time ending damage.

I took the thing up to Scotland and we went up to a place on the west coast of Scotland and then almost at once I was called down to the Admiralty and I went to see the Director of Torpedoes and Mining, a man called Captain Middleton, and he said, look, we think we've got an acoustic mine.
And I said, well, why do you think so?
Are you sure?
And he sent me around to see the intelligence people.
And I was convinced they were right.
They had got an acoustic line.
So I then went back to the director of torpedoes and mining.
He said, I want you to do something about this.
Leave the people in Scotland and do something about it.
So I said, all right, what do you want me to do?
He said, I don't know.
That's your business.
Go and do something.
So I suddenly...
had to start a new organization for dealing with acoustic mines.
And very soon I found myself in charge of all development of minesweeping, development of methods of minesweeping from the civilian side.
I had a naval officer number.
And what I did was we'd been operating in, we'd taken over a dance hall.
We'd been operating in this dance hall.
And we'd left it because the whole place had been wrecked.
And we burnt the pier later.
Anyway, I decided to go back into this place.
It was the only place I was quite sure I could get quickly.
So we went back into this dance hall and told the post office that the wicked people who'd had it last had removed all the telephones.
Would they please come and put a new lot of telephones in?
And we also set up a little show in Hairidge.
And we started off after acoustic mines.
And this was a real success.
No acoustic mine practically ever sank a ship again.
We had wonderful fun with this.
And, well, I don't think there's any point in going into it in detail, but this was a new thing to me, a new sort of world, quite rather different from the ordinary scientific world.
It was not a competitive thing.
It was a group of people with a common object trying to achieve a particular object.
And also, of course, it was to some extent
the effort to inflate one's own organization, the typical thing, the Parkinson syndrome, where you try and build up your own organization.
And by this time, of course, we were more or less official wizards.
We could get anything we wanted.
I mean, there was a transformation now.
Before the war, we couldn't get 10 pounds.
Now we could have anything we wanted.
And we presumed on this.
We did anything we bloody well liked.
a young man coming in one day and saying, look, I hope you don't mind, I've taken over the Portsmouth Yacht Club.
Well, the Portsmouth Yacht Club is a very sort of upper-crust organisation.
And this young man had simply gone in and commandeered it.
And I said, well, I suppose it's all right, what do you want it for?
He told me what he wanted to do there.
And I said, well, all right, go and get the paperwork done, go and see the administrative people, tell them to go through the paperwork and compensate the Yacht Club and all that.
And we took over...
A rich man's yacht, I remember, because we thought it might be nice for some purpose or other.
We might want it to go somewhere.
And unfortunately, it got hit by a shell coming through the Straits of Douma, so we never really got it.
And well, then we burnt the pier associated with this dance hall.
And then shortly after that, the whole place got burnt, our firefighting party.
was engaged in rescuing a lady we all liked very much in a local pub.
She was a barmaid in a local pub, a girl called Piggy.
By the way, I should have said the only bit that I wish to place restrictions on is the little piece about the incompetence of the people at Portsmouth before I took charge.
It's only about half a minute.
I don't want the rest of this, you're quite free to do as you like.
but simply the bit about the man I stood on the pier with, and he waved his hand, and I said, move along ten feet, and the bit about how we got the six people removed from the project.
I would like that not to be used without your asking me whether I approve the passage.
I shan't be unduly restrictive about it, but I've just got to guard myself against accusations of libel.
Right.
Well, anyway, we then...
We then decided that Portsmouth had become uninhabitable.
We went up to Edinburgh and we set up an organisation there.
We took over part of a school and set ourselves up there.
It was a curious incident in which I was driving around Edinburgh looking for a suitable building and I saw a great big building on the top of a hill.
I said, let's go and look at that.
What is it?
They said, oh, that is Fitties College, which is a public school.
Well, I thought it's time I got my own back on the headmaster of a public school.
So I went in to see the headmaster and told him we were thinking of taking over the school.
And I got no result at all, because he just said, that would be a good thing, because I'm sure the public schools are finished, and we should get a lot of compensation.
And then I had to confess all I was going to take over was one of the houses.
And he was worried about this, because he said the army were at present occupying it, and he thought they'd do more damage than we would.
And I said this was a superficial view.
The army would undoubtedly wreck the building.
But we would do much more than wreck it.
We would build attachments, build tanks all around it.
And we would knock down partition walls.
We would do real structural damage.
Whereas the army would only sort of muck up the paintwork and write rude words on the ceilings and that kind of thing.
And so he said he was very well satisfied with this.
I imagine they had to rebuild a building to finish it.
Well, anyway, we had another of these successes.
I think the sinkings from mining never again reached 10% of the sinkings from submarines in any month in the war or something like that.
I forget the actual figures.
I published an account of this to which I can give you a reference.
Did you have any cooperation with the US Navy research in this area?
Well, we had a funny thing.
We decided the US Navy were not taking the mining problem seriously.
Because for them, it was potentially very serious.
The submarines could operate off the east coast of the United States, and they could lay mines and block up the harbors.
And so we asked the US Naval attache to come down and have dinner with us.
And he came down, and we talked to him and told him what we were spending and what we were doing.
And I got the impression we weren't having much effect.
And what I didn't realize was that in dealing with an American bureaucracy, one is not fighting friction, one's fighting inertia.
It gets moving rather slowly, but every bit of pushing you do has its effect.
It's not like when you push against friction, nothing happens until you reach a critical push.
So that in fact, we went on pushing much too long.
And an enormous and very extravagant organization appeared over here, particularly for protecting ships and magnetic mines.
And we spent the rest of the war trying to damp it down on the grounds that it was an extravagance.
Well, anyway, at this point, somewhere about the beginning of 41, I began to feel that we'd taken the guilt off the subject of mines and things, and no ships much were being sunk.
We'd done a good job on hypothetical minds and what we might do in the future, and I asked to get out of it.
So I then got out of it.
I'd learned a great deal about how the Navy works, about the Navy, about how to work on a large scale at sea, how to do all kinds of things.
And I'd learned about naval officers and the sort of things you could do with them and the things you couldn't.
We'd survived various disasters in which we'd bust up bits of battleships, that kind of thing.
We once broke the back of an American force track destroyer, I remember, in a misfortune.
Well, and all these kinds of things.
Well, then I went up to the Admiralty, and I went to work with the Director of Scientific Research in the Admiralty.

And very soon after this, I was a rash young man, a young man in a hurry, and I decided that the original place I'd been to at the beginning of the war, the anti-submarine establishment, the direction of it had become intolerable, and we must remove the direction of it.
And I don't know if the man concerned is dead, and I think I'd better restrict this piece.
But I said,

to the director of scientific research that he must get rid of this man and remove him to somewhere else, that he was not running a good show in the anti-submarine side, it was ineffective, he was an egomaniac, and was keeping a very tight, close control over anything, he was not getting the best out of his people, and it was going to be a bloody awful row.
And the director of scientific research, Daryl Charlie Wright, refused to remove the man.
And I said, well, I won't work for you.
If you say that, I won't work for you.
I'm walking out on you.
You can do what you bloody well like about it.
And then a very curious state of affairs ensued.
I went across the road and went to see Patrick Blackett, who was just inventing operations analysis, and went to work with him.
And I kept forgetting that I wasn't on speaking terms with Charlie Wright, the representative of research.
He used to cut me in the street.
And finally, there was a
thing called the Midnight Follies, which was a meeting once a month with the first sea lord, and most of the other sea lords, to have an account of the state of the war.
And about, I saw right there, and I thought it's absurd that you continue this argument, so I sat down, obviously across a rather narrow table.
He looked this way, and he looked that way, and he wouldn't look me in the face.
And finally, after the thing broke up, I saw him standing,
in front of the first sea lord and the third sea lord, who was his own boss.
And I knew that he was frightened of admirals.
And so I went up to him and said, all right, it is nice to see you.
And he looked at me.
He looked both ways.
And he saw these two admirals standing there.
And he put his hand on my shoulder and said, my dear Bullard, it is indeed nice to see you again.
And ever since then, we've been buddies.
And this curious thing, the last time I had anything to do with him was a few months ago.
I was in Victoria, British Columbia.
And I called him up and said, look, I'm awfully sorry.
I was hoping to come and see you, but I can't.
I haven't got time.
I'll see you next time I'm here.
And he said, I don't think you will.
And he died a month later.
He was a dear man in a completely wrong job.
A gentle, intelligent man who, after he retired three times in all, and he had this job as Director of Scientific Research in the Admiralty, which he was completely unable to carry out, really.
It was a disaster.
Well, I think because he's dead, and because he was a friend of mine, that little piece ought to be restricted in the sense I'd like to know what people say about it before they use it.
Well, then I got into operations analysis and direction of the war, use of facilities.
The idea was that the war was by now getting pretty far along.
This was getting on in the middle or late 41, probably August 41.
It was dubious if any new technical developments would really have a critical effect.
And then, of course, not very long after this, the Americans and the Russians came in at the end of December 41, and the war was clearly won.
It was only a matter of time.
And the important thing was to have rational views on the use of forces, things like the size of convoys, questions of this sort.
I started taking interest in all these questions.
It didn't really suit me all that well, I don't think.
I hadn't got Blackett's optimism of the importance of what we were doing.
And I rather drifted off into the interpretation of intelligence in terms of operations.
And I had a curious job for a while looking after intelligence on V weapons.
The flying bombs and rockets.
I was the admiralty representative on a committee on this subject.
And I went there, and I was also a member of this curious little committee.
There was a high level service committee, which I was the admiralty representative.
And then there was a working level committee on intelligence connected with these things, a very curious kind.
The war office was represented by a man who ran a chain of laundries in peacetime.
The invasion armies were represented by an Oxford philosopher.
I represented the Admiralty.
And the Air Force was represented by the dumbest air commodore anyone who had ever seen.
And this was a very curious body indeed.
I mean, very important things hung on it.
How much effort should you use?
to destroy the flying bomb sites in France.
It meant diverting bomber effort from Germany.
What was the proper balance on this?
How did you persuade the Air Force that the threat was serious?
And it wasn't just the Air Force maintained.
It was just a method of diverting effort from the bombing of Germany.
It was all a spoof.
And all this kind of thing.
And I got deeply interested in this.
And then in the middle of it, I suddenly got pulled out
And if you've got to go now... No, no, I'm trying to keep the tape.
Ah, yes, sure.

Well, in the middle of it, there was trouble, because Duncan Sands, who was Churchill's son-in-law, was chairman of the high-level committee, and the air ministry representative was the commander-in-chief of fighter command.
And the commander-in-chief of fighter command was a man called Roderick Hill, who was a wonderful man.
I was devoted to him.
And he was getting in trouble.
He wouldn't bring an officer with him who knew about the details, and he really didn't know the details, and he was making an ass of himself.
And it was an embarrassment to Sands and everyone, and Sands didn't like him.
And Sands suggested that I join his staff and look after all the details of this.
And Hill said he wouldn't have anyone recommended by Sands, because Sands was not universally popular, to the least of it.
Then at a cocktail party, I met Hill again.
And he said, look, are you the man Sands is trying to foist on me?
And I said, yes.
And he said, I believe we've got a deal.
So I went out to work at Fighter Command, and essentially to protect Hill from politicians.
Various people in Sands' entourage, Sands was Churchill's son-in-law and member of parliament.
the minister, and he was sending his dogs' bodies out, who went through the files of Fighter Command, looking for rude letters about sands, of which there were plenty.
And my job was to keep these people out of the place, without defending sands so much that there was a row.
And so I was normally head of the operations analysis of Fighter Command, but in fact I was political protector to the commander-in-chief.
And this was really most entertaining.
And after the sights had been overrun in France, I said, well, this is now finished.
I'll go back to the Admiralty.
So I went off back to the Admiralty.
And a month or so later, Roddy Hill called me up and said, look, would you go over to France and see that we don't have a lot of fuss there?
Because there were rockets being fired at Antwerp.
And so I had a lovely time.
I said, well, look, give me a staff of some sort.
And he supplied a group captain and a squad leader and a couple of WAFs and that kind of thing.
And we went over just after Christmas, I think it was, 44, to set up an organization in France to make sure that no one could complain about what was happening about flying bombs in France.
And we decided the war was obviously won, and we might as well see how big an organization we could set up before it finished.
We got up to 2,000, I think.
We published a daily newspaper of some sort in Paris.
I think we actually laid a cable under the channel.
We certainly had a dedicated cable under the channel of our own for transmitting information.
